items.title: Arkansas Amendment Era (1874–Present)
items.description: Since the adoption of the 1874 Constitution, Arkansas has operated under a framework intentionally designed to resist structural change. The Amendment Era is defined by a continuous struggle between popular efforts to modernize governance and elite efforts to contain or procedurally block reform.

items.title: Arkansas Constitution of 1836
items.description: Arkansas became a state in 1836 amid rapid westward expansion, Indigenous removal, and the expansion of slavery.

items.title: Decision: Analyze Constitutions as Power Architecture
items.description: Frame every Arkansas constitution as a designed power architecture reflecting the interests and exclusions of its drafters.

items.title: Decision: Classify the 1861 Constitution as a Failure-State Constitution
items.description: Define the 1861 Constitution as a failure-state constitution produced to preserve elite control amid collapsing institutions.

items.title: Decision: Classify the 1864 Constitution as an Administrative Bridge
items.description: Define the 1864 Constitution as an administrative bridge between Confederate collapse and formal Reconstruction.

items.title: Decision: Frame the 1868 Constitution as Enforced Democratic Realignment
items.description: Analyze the 1868 Constitution as an externally enforced realignment of political power rather than an internal reform movement.

items.title: Decision: Frame the 1868 Constitution as Enforced Democratic Realignment
items.description: Analyze the 1868 Constitution as an externally enforced realignment of political power rather than an internal reform movement.

items.title: Decision: Frame the 1874 Constitution as Structural Counter-Revolution
items.description: Analyze the 1874 Constitution as a deliberate counter-revolution designed to entrench elite control and resist reform.
